intro: Paraboea tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly paraboea, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, or tomentose, foliage. The plant typically grows as an erect shrub with opposite, lance-shaped leaves. It produces small, clustered flowers that are usually white or pale pink, attracting various pollinators. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
